The morning sun cast long shadows across the dusty streets of Johannesburg as Piet Koetzee adjusted his worn leather tool belt and squinted at the electrical meter before him. Twenty-three years he'd been reading these contraptions, twenty-three years of crawling through ceiling spaces and rewiring suburban homes, and still the sight of perfectly balanced numbers gave him a small thrill of satisfaction.

"Another job well done," he muttered to himself, wiping sweat from his weathered brow with the back of his sleeve. The December heat was already becoming unbearable at half past eight in the morning, and Piet knew it would only get worse as the day progressed.

His van, a battered white Toyota Hiace that had seen better decades, sat parked under the shade of a blue gum tree. The vehicle bore the scars of countless encounters with Johannesburg's notorious potholes, its panels dented and paint faded to an indeterminate color somewhere between white and beige. But it ran, mostly, and that was all that mattered to a man like Piet.

As he loaded his tools into the back of the van, his phone buzzed against his hip. The caller ID showed his wife Sarah's name, and he smiled despite himself.

"Morning, my love," he answered, settling into the driver's seat.

"Piet, have you seen the newspaper today?" Sarah's voice crackled through the phone's speaker, excitement barely contained.

"You know I don't read that rubbish, Sarah. Nothing but politics and crime."

"Page fourteen, sports section. Trust me on this one."

Piet sighed and reached for the crumpled copy of The Star that lay on his passenger seat, folded open to the racing results from the night before. He flipped through the pages until he found what Sarah was referring to, and his eyes widened as he read the headline: "Annual Gauteng Pie Eating Championship Seeks Final Contestant."

The article explained that due to a last-minute withdrawal, the organizers were looking for one more participant to complete the field of twelve competitors for Saturday's final. Applications were being accepted until Thursday evening, with the winner receiving a cash prize of fifty thousand rand and the coveted Golden Fork trophy.

"Sarah, this is..." Piet's voice trailed off as he read the details again.

"This is your chance, Piet! You've been talking about entering one of these competitions for years."

She wasn't wrong. Piet had always possessed what could generously be called a healthy appetite, and what Sarah less generously referred to as "a bottomless pit where normal people keep their stomachs." At company braais, family gatherings, and church potlucks, Piet was legendary for his ability to consume vast quantities of food without apparent effort or consequence.

The idea of turning this particular talent into something resembling glory had always appealed to him, though he'd never quite found the courage to take the plunge. Competitive eating seemed like something that happened to other people, people with sponsors and training regimens and social media followings.

"What if I'm not good enough?" he asked, though even as the words left his mouth he knew they were ridiculous. Last month at his nephew's birthday party, he'd single-handedly finished an entire chocolate cake after the children had lost interest, and that was just as a warm-up to the main meal.

"Piet Koetzee, I've watched you eat six boerewors rolls at a single sitting without breaking a sweat. If anyone can win this thing, it's you."

The application process turned out to be surprisingly straightforward. A brief medical clearance from his doctor, confirming he was healthy enough to participate in what the form diplomatically termed "vigorous digestive activity," and a short essay explaining why he deserved the final spot.

Piet agonized over the essay for the better part of an evening, sitting at his kitchen table with a pen in one hand and a beer in the other, trying to find words that would convince the judges he was worthy. In the end, he kept it simple: "I've been eating pies my whole life, and I reckon I'm pretty good at it. Give me a chance to prove it."

The call came three days later, while Piet was elbow-deep in the fuse box of a suburban house in Randburg. The voice on the other end of the line was crisp and professional, belonging to a woman who introduced herself as Monica from the championship organizing committee.

"Mr. Koetzee, we're pleased to inform you that your application has been accepted. You'll be competing this Saturday at the Wanderers Club in Illovo, starting at two PM sharp."

Piet nearly dropped his phone into the tangle of wires he was working on. "Are you serious?"

"Completely serious, Mr. Koetzee. We'll need you to arrive by one-thirty for registration and a brief safety orientation. The competition format is straightforward - you'll have fifteen minutes to consume as many meat pies as possible. The contestant who eats the most wins."

After hanging up, Piet sat in stunned silence for several minutes, staring at the electrical panel without really seeing it. Then, gradually, a grin spread across his face that was so wide it made his cheeks ache.

That evening, Sarah insisted on taking him out to dinner to celebrate, though she made him promise not to overdo it.

"You need to start training properly," she said, cutting into her grilled chicken with surgical precision. "This isn't just about eating a lot anymore, Piet. This is about technique, strategy, endurance."

Piet nodded seriously, though privately he wondered how complicated it could be. Pie goes in mouth, mouth chews, stomach receives pie, repeat until victory. Still, he appreciated Sarah's enthusiasm for his newfound athletic career.

The next few days passed in a blur of preparation and nervous energy. Piet researched competitive eating techniques online, learning about jaw exercises and stomach capacity training. He practiced with various pie types, timing himself and experimenting with different approaches to maximize his consumption rate.

Friday evening found him sitting in his living room, surrounded by empty pie tins and feeling cautiously optimistic about his chances. His practice sessions had gone well - his personal best stood at seven standard meat pies in fifteen minutes, which he figured had to be competitive with whatever amateurs had signed up for the contest.

"You're going to do brilliantly," Sarah said, settling onto the couch beside him. "I can feel it."

Piet squeezed her hand, trying to project confidence he didn't entirely feel. "Just promise me you'll still love me if I come in last place."

"Piet, I've loved you through twenty-six years of marriage, three job changes, and that unfortunate incident with the Christmas pudding. I think I can handle watching you lose a pie eating contest."

Saturday morning arrived with the kind of perfect summer weather that made Piet grateful to live in Johannesburg despite its many flaws. The sky was cloudless, the temperature was perfect, and he felt as ready as a man could feel for such an endeavor.

He'd set his alarm for eight AM, giving himself plenty of time to shower, eat a light breakfast, and make the drive to Illovo. The Wanderers Club was perhaps forty-five minutes away in normal traffic, and Piet had factored in extra time for Saturday afternoon congestion.

Sarah kissed him goodbye at the front door, straightening his collar and brushing an imaginary speck of dust from his shoulder.

"Bring home that trophy, my champion," she said, and Piet felt his chest swell with something that might have been pride or might have been indigestion from his practice session the night before.

The van started on the third try, which Piet took as a good omen. He'd been meaning to have the starter motor looked at for months, but like most of his van's minor ailments, it was the sort of thing that seemed manageable until it suddenly wasn't.

He pulled out of his driveway at twelve-fifteen, giving himself what he considered a comfortable cushion of time for the journey ahead. The radio was playing some forgettable pop song, but Piet found himself humming along anyway, drumming his fingers against the steering wheel in anticipation of the afternoon ahead.

Traffic through the city center was lighter than expected, and Piet began to think he might arrive early enough to scout out the competition and maybe get a feel for the venue. He'd never been to the Wanderers Club before, but he imagined it would be suitably grand for such an important sporting event.

It was somewhere around Melville that the van began to make the noise.At first, Piet thought the sound was coming from outside the van - perhaps a motorcycle with a faulty exhaust pipe or construction work somewhere nearby. It was a rhythmic grinding noise, like metal scraping against metal, accompanied by an intermittent clicking that seemed to sync with the rotation of his wheels. He turned down the radio and listened more carefully, his stomach sinking as he realized the sounds were definitely coming from beneath his own vehicle.

"Come on, old girl," he muttered, patting the dashboard with the kind of gentle encouragement he usually reserved for temperamental electrical circuits. "Not today. Any day but today." The van continued forward without any obvious loss of power, but the grinding noise grew more pronounced as he navigated the gentle hills leading toward the northern suburbs. Piet found himself gripping the steering wheel more tightly, his knuckles white against the cracked vinyl covering.

He considered pulling over to investigate, but a glance at his watch showed it was already twelve-forty. Even if traffic remained light, he was cutting things closer than he'd intended, and he couldn't afford to lose time diagnosing whatever was wrong with his increasingly unreliable mode of transportation. The noise was concerning, certainly, but the van was still moving, still responding to the accelerator and brake pedal, still getting him closer to his destination with each passing minute.

As he turned onto Jan Smuts Avenue, the grinding intensified to the point where other drivers were beginning to stare. A woman in a silver BMW pulled alongside him at a traffic light and gestured toward his wheels, her expression suggesting she thought he might be unaware of the mechanical symphony emanating from his vehicle. Piet smiled and waved, trying to project an air of confidence he absolutely did not feel. The light turned green, and he pressed the accelerator perhaps more gently than usual, willing the van to hold together for just a few more kilometers.

The irony of the situation was not lost on him. Here he was, a man who made his living fixing things that were broken, completely helpless to address whatever was failing in his own vehicle. He knew enough about cars to understand that grinding noises were rarely indicative of minor problems, and clicking sounds usually meant something important was coming loose or wearing out. But his expertise lay in circuits and wiring, not in the mechanical mysteries hidden beneath steel and rubber and grease.

By the time he reached Rosebank, the van was producing what could generously be described as a percussion ensemble of automotive distress. The grinding had been joined by a new squealing sound that seemed to crescendo whenever he applied the brakes, and there was now a distinct vibration running through the steering wheel that made his hands tingle with each revolution of the wheels. Other motorists were giving him a noticeably wide berth, as if mechanical failure might be contagious.

Piet began to calculate alternative transportation options in his head. He could call a taxi, but that would mean abandoning his van on the side of the road, and he had no idea how long it might take to get one during the Saturday afternoon rush. Public transport was theoretically possible, but the combination of buses and minibus taxis required to get him from wherever he might break down to the Wanderers Club would almost certainly make him late for registration. Sarah could come and fetch him, but she was visiting her sister in Krugersdorp and wouldn't be able to get to him quickly enough.

The thought of missing the competition because of mechanical failure filled him with a frustration that surprised him with its intensity. Three days ago, he hadn't even known this contest existed. Now, the prospect of not being able to participate felt like a genuine tragedy, as if something important and long-awaited was slipping through his fingers through no fault of his own. He'd practiced, he'd prepared, he'd gotten himself mentally ready for what might be the most unusual athletic endeavor of his fifty-one years, and now his van was threatening to derail everything.

As he crested the hill approaching Illovo, the engine began to make a new sound - a rattling that seemed to come from deep within the motor itself. Piet's knowledge of automotive mechanics might have been limited, but he knew enough to recognize the sound of expensive trouble brewing. The temperature gauge on his dashboard was climbing toward the red zone, and there was now a faint smell of something burning that he couldn't quite identify.

"Just a little further," he said aloud, though whether he was addressing the van, himself, or some higher power remained unclear. "Five more minutes. Maybe ten. That's all I need." The Wanderers Club couldn't be far now - he'd passed several landmarks he recognized from the directions he'd printed out the night before. If he could just nurse the van through the next few traffic lights, he might be able to coast into the parking area and deal with the mechanical crisis after the competition was over.

The van responded to his plea by producing a sound unlike anything Piet had ever heard from a motor vehicle - a grinding, squealing, rattling cacophony that caused pedestrians on the sidewalk to turn and stare. The steering wheel was now vibrating so violently that it was difficult to maintain a straight course, and the smell of burning had intensified to the point where he was beginning to worry about fire.

But there, just ahead on his left, he could see the entrance to the Wanderers Club. The gate was flanked by stone pillars and manicured hedges, and there was a discrete sign that confirmed he'd found the right place. A security guard in a crisp uniform was checking vehicles as they entered, and Piet could see several cars already parked in what appeared to be a designated area near the main clubhouse.

He turned into the entrance with a sense of relief so profound it was almost euphoric. The guard approached his window with a clipboard and a professional smile that flickered only slightly when the full symphony of mechanical distress reached his ears. Piet rolled down his window, grateful that the electrical system, at least, was still functioning properly.

"Good afternoon, sir. Are you here for the pie eating championship?" The guard's tone remained polite, though he was clearly making an effort not to stare at the van's various dents and scrapes, or to react to the increasingly concerning sounds coming from beneath the hood.

"Yes, I'm one of the contestants. Piet Koetzee." He reached into his shirt pocket for the confirmation letter he'd printed out that morning, his hands shaking slightly from the steering wheel's vibrations. "I know I'm cutting it a bit close, but I had some, uh, transportation difficulties."

The guard consulted his clipboard and nodded. "You're on the list, Mr. Koetzee. Contestant number seven. You'll want to park over there with the other participants, and then head straight to the clubhouse for registration. They're planning to start the safety briefing in about ten minutes."

Piet thanked him and rolled up his window, then carefully drove toward the designated parking area. Other contestants were getting out of their vehicles - a mix of ordinary sedans and SUVs that looked exponentially more reliable than his own automotive disaster. He recognized one of the men from a newspaper photo he'd seen online, a previous winner who'd returned to defend his title. The man was stretching and doing what appeared to be jaw exercises, his face set in the kind of focused concentration Piet associated with professional athletes.

He found an empty parking space as far from the other vehicles as possible, hoping to minimize the embarrassment when someone inevitably had to help him figure out what had gone wrong with his van. Piet sat in the sudden silence of his van for a moment, collecting himself and trying to push the mechanical disaster out of his mind. Through the windshield, he could see the other contestants making their way toward the clubhouse, a grand building of red brick and white columns that spoke of old money and established tradition. The manicured lawns stretched in every direction, punctuated by ancient oak trees that provided patches of welcome shade in the afternoon heat. This was a far cry from the working-class neighborhoods where Piet spent most of his days, and he felt a familiar flutter of nervousness at finding himself so clearly out of his usual element.

He climbed out of the van and immediately heard the distinctive sound of metal cooling and contracting, accompanied by what sounded suspiciously like a small drip of fluid hitting the pavement beneath the engine. A quick glance confirmed his suspicions - there was already a small puddle of something dark forming under the front of the vehicle. Whatever had gone wrong was apparently still going wrong, even with the engine switched off. Piet made a mental note to deal with it after the competition, then grabbed his wallet and keys and headed toward the clubhouse, trying to project more confidence than he felt.

The entrance hall of the Wanderers Club was everything Piet had expected and more. High ceilings, polished marble floors, and oil paintings of distinguished-looking men in cricket whites lined the walls. The air conditioning was a blessed relief after the heat outside, and Piet paused for a moment to let his body temperature adjust while he got his bearings. A discrete sign near the reception desk directed pie eating championship participants toward a private dining room on the second floor, and he followed the arrows through a maze of corridors that seemed designed to showcase the club's illustrious sporting history.

The registration table was set up outside the dining room, staffed by the same crisp-voiced Monica who had called to confirm his participation. She looked exactly as Piet had imagined - professionally dressed, efficiently organized, and possessed of the kind of unflappable composure that came from years of managing sporting events. Her smile was warm but businesslike as she looked up from her clipboard and extended her hand.

"Mr. Koetzee, I presume? We were beginning to worry you might not make it. I'm Monica Henderson, the event coordinator." She gestured toward a chair beside the registration table where Piet could see various forms and documents waiting for his signature. "We just need to get some paperwork sorted, and then you can meet your fellow competitors before we start the briefing."

The forms were mercifully straightforward - liability waivers, medical disclaimers, and media release agreements that would allow the event organizers to photograph and film the competition for promotional purposes. Piet worked through them methodically, his electrician's training having taught him to read every document carefully before signing anything. The legal language was dense and occasionally alarming, particularly the sections dealing with potential medical complications arising from rapid food consumption, but he supposed such precautions were necessary when dealing with what was essentially an extreme sport.

"You'll be wearing competitor number seven," Monica explained, handing him a plastic bib with his number printed in large, bold digits. "The pies are standard commercially produced meat pies, approximately two hundred grams each, supplied by the same manufacturer used in all official championship events. No condiments or beverages are permitted during the competition period, though we'll have water available afterward for rehydration purposes."

Piet nodded along, though privately he was beginning to realize how little he actually knew about the technical aspects of competitive eating. His practice sessions at home had been informal affairs, lacking the precision and standardization that apparently characterized official events. The pies he'd been training with were homemade varieties from his local bakery, and he had no idea how they might compare to whatever officially sanctioned products would be placed in front of him in a few minutes.

"The judging is quite straightforward," Monica continued, seemingly oblivious to his growing uncertainty. "Each pie consumed must be completely swallowed before the fifteen-minute time limit expires. Partially consumed pies don't count toward your final total, and any, ah, reversal of the eating process results in immediate disqualification. We have medical personnel standing by, though in fifteen years of organizing these events, we've never had a serious incident."

The briefing room was already filled with eleven other contestants when Piet entered, and he was struck immediately by how seriously his competitors were taking the whole affair. Several of them were doing stretching exercises, working their jaw muscles and rotating their necks as if preparing for a marathon. Others sat in focused meditation, their eyes closed and breathing deep and regular. One man in his thirties was practicing what appeared to be speed-chewing motions with a piece of gum, his jaw working with mechanical precision.

Piet found an empty chair near the back of the room and tried to assess his competition. The defending champion was a lean man in his forties named Derek Mills, who had the kind of wiry build that seemed to defy physics when it came to food consumption. Beside him sat a younger competitor who introduced himself as Kevin Patel, a university student who claimed to have set several unofficial eating records at campus events. There was also a middle-aged woman named Jennifer van Rooyen who had apparently driven down from Pretoria specifically for this competition, and whose intense focus suggested she was not here merely for the novelty of the experience.

The other contestants represented a similar mix of ages and backgrounds, united only by their apparent confidence in their eating abilities and their serious approach to what many people would consider a frivolous pursuit. Piet began to wonder if he was out of his depth, if his casual backyard practice sessions had prepared him for what was clearly a more competitive environment than he had anticipated. These people had done their homework, developed strategies, possibly even consulted with coaches or nutritionists about optimal pie consumption techniques.

A tournament official entered the room carrying a clipboard and wearing the kind of serious expression usually reserved for Olympic events. He introduced himself as the head judge and launched into a detailed explanation of the rules, regulations, and procedures that would govern the next hour of their lives. The competition would take place in the club's main dining room, with contestants seated at a long table facing an audience of spectators, media representatives, and family members. Each contestant would be provided with an identical stack of twenty meat pies, arranged on regulation plates and positioned for optimal access.

"The key to success in competitive eating," the judge explained with the gravity of a university lecturer, "is finding the right balance between speed and sustainability. Eating too quickly can lead to premature fullness or digestive complications that will limit your overall capacity. Eating too slowly means you'll run out of time before reaching your maximum potential consumption. Most successful contestants develop a rhythm that allows them to maintain steady progress throughout the entire fifteen-minute period."

Piet tried to absorb this information while simultaneously questioning every assumption he had made about his natural eating abilities. Perhaps there was more strategy involved than he had realized. Maybe his instinctive approach to food consumption, developed over decades of hearty meals and family gatherings, would not translate directly to the pressures and constraints of timed competition eating. The judge continued his briefing with detailed explanations of acceptable eating techniques, hydration strategies, and the importance of proper posture for maintaining optimal stomach positioning throughout the event.

As the official presentation concluded and contestants began making their final preparations, Piet excused himself to visit the restroom and gather his thoughts. The facilities at the Wanderers Club were as immaculate as everything else he had seen, all polished fixtures and soft lighting that seemed designed to soothe jangled nerves. He splashed cold water on his face and studied his reflection in the mirror, trying to summon the confidence that had carried him through the application process and practice sessions.

The man looking back at him was clearly nervous but determined, weathered by years of physical work and practical problem-solving, possessed of the kind of steady patience that came from spending most of his adult life figuring out how to make broken things work again. Those skills had served him well in countless situations over the years, and he had to believe they would serve him now, even in circumstances as unusual as competitive pie eating. After all, this was just another kind of problem to be solved, another challenge that required the right combination of technique, endurance, and mental focus.

When he returned to the briefing room, he found the other contestants engaged in final preparations that ranged from the practical to the seemingly superstitious. Derek Mills was doing elaborate stretching exercises that appeared to target every muscle group involved in eating, while Kevin Patel was reviewing what looked like handwritten notes about optimal chewing patterns. Jennifer van Rooyen was sitting quietly with her eyes closed, apparently visualizing her approach to the competition ahead. One contestant was listening to music through earbuds, nodding his head in rhythm to whatever motivational soundtrack he had chosen for the occasion.

Monica appeared in the doorway and announced that it was time to move to the main dining room for the competition itself. The contestants filed out in a mixture of nervous excitement and grim determination, like soldiers heading into battle or athletes taking the field for a championship game. Piet fell in step with the group, trying to maintain the kind of calm focus that had gotten him through difficult electrical jobs and challenging household repairs over the years.

The main dining room had been transformed for the occasion, with a long table positioned at the center of the room and chairs arranged in precise formation for the twelve contestants. Television cameras were positioned at strategic angles, and there was a small audience of spectators seated at tables around the periphery of the room. Piet caught sight of what appeared to be local sports reporters, their notebooks ready and cameras positioned for optimal coverage of whatever was about to unfold.

Each contestant's position was marked with their competition number, and Piet found his seat toward the middle of the long table. In front of him sat a stack of twenty meat pies arranged with military precision on white ceramic plates, accompanied by cloth napkins and a small placard bearing his name and contestant number. The pies looked identical to each other and remarkably similar to the commercial varieties he had practiced with, which provided a small measure of reassurance as he settled into his chair and surveyed the battlefield ahead.

The head judge took his position at a podium facing the contestants, a stopwatch in his hand and a microphone clipped to his shirt collar. The room fell silent except for the quiet hum of air conditioning and the distant sound of kitchen staff cleaning up somewhere beyond the dining room doors. Piet looked left and right at his fellow competitors, noting the intense concentration on their faces and the way several of them were flexing their jaw muscles in final preparation for the ordeal ahead.

"Ladies and gentlemen, contestants and spectators, welcome to the Annual Gauteng Pie Eating Championship," the judge announced, his voice carrying clearly through the room's sound system. "We have twelve brave competitors ready to test their eating abilities against some of the finest meat pies Johannesburg has to offer. The rules are simple - fifteen minutes on the clock, and the contestant who consumes the most complete pies will be declared our champion and will take home the Golden Fork trophy along with a cash prize of fifty thousand rand."The judge raised his hand, and Piet could feel his heart hammering against his ribs with an intensity that seemed disproportionate to the task ahead. Around him, the other contestants had fallen into various states of focused readiness - some bouncing slightly in their chairs, others sitting perfectly still with their hands positioned precisely beside their first pie. The television cameras hummed quietly as they adjusted their angles, and somewhere in the audience Piet could hear the soft murmur of spectators placing last-minute bets on their favored competitors.

"Contestants, you may begin in three... two... one..." The judge's stopwatch clicked, and suddenly the dining room erupted into a frenzy of synchronized eating that was unlike anything Piet had ever witnessed.

The sound was extraordinary - twelve people simultaneously biting, chewing, and swallowing with mechanical efficiency, punctuated by the clink of plates and the rustle of napkins. Derek Mills, the defending champion, had already finished his first pie and was reaching for his second while Piet was still working through his initial bite. The university student Kevin seemed to have adopted a strategy of breaking each pie into smaller pieces before consuming them in rapid succession, while Jennifer van Rooyen was methodically working through her first pie with the kind of steady rhythm that suggested she planned to maintain her pace throughout the entire fifteen-minute period.

Piet forced himself to focus on his own technique rather than watching his competitors, though it was difficult to ignore the impressive speed at which some of them were working. His first pie was standard commercial quality - flaky pastry filled with seasoned mince that was neither particularly good nor particularly bad, exactly the kind of unremarkable food that could be consumed quickly without offensive flavors getting in the way. He finished it in what felt like a reasonable time and reached for his second, trying to establish the kind of sustainable rhythm the judge had mentioned during the briefing.

By the three-minute mark, it became clear that the competition was going to be closer than Piet had anticipated. Derek Mills had established an early lead with four pies completed, but Kevin Patel was close behind at three and a half, and several other contestants including Jennifer were maintaining a steady pace that kept them in contention. Piet himself had finished two complete pies and was making good progress on his third, which put him somewhere in the middle of the pack but still within striking distance of the leaders.

The physical demands of competitive eating were becoming apparent as the clock continued to tick. Piet's jaw muscles were already beginning to ache from the constant chewing motion, and he could feel his stomach expanding to accommodate the growing volume of food. The meat pies were substantial - each one probably equivalent to a normal lunch portion - and the cumulative effect of eating multiple servings in rapid succession was more challenging than his practice sessions had suggested it would be. Around the table, he could see other contestants beginning to show signs of strain, their initial enthusiasm giving way to the grim determination required to push through physical discomfort.

At the five-minute mark, the judge called out the time remaining, and Piet realized with some surprise that he had found his rhythm. His third pie was nearly gone, and he was already eyeing his fourth with the kind of calculated assessment that had served him well in his electrical work. The key seemed to be maintaining steady progress without rushing to the point where his eating became inefficient or his stomach rebelled against the pace he was setting. Several contestants around the table appeared to have pushed too hard in the early going and were now slowing down noticeably, their faces flushed and their breathing labored.

Derek Mills was still in the lead with six pies completed, but his advantage had narrowed as some of his competitors settled into sustainable rhythms that allowed them to maintain steady progress. Kevin Patel had matched Derek's total, while Jennifer van Rooyen was just one pie behind at five. A heavyset man named Andrew who had been sitting quietly at the far end of the table had emerged as an unexpected contender, methodically working through his fifth pie with the kind of focused concentration that suggested he had plenty left in reserve.

Piet finished his fourth pie and paused for a moment to assess his condition, something he had learned to do instinctively during long days of physical work. His stomach was definitely full, but not uncomfortably so, and his jaw muscles were sore but still functional. More importantly, he could feel that he had found an eating pace that felt sustainable for the remaining ten minutes of competition. The initial nervousness had given way to the kind of methodical focus he brought to complex electrical problems - identifying the most efficient approach and then executing it with steady persistence until the job was done.

The middle phase of the competition brought new challenges as the novelty wore off and the physical reality of the task became more demanding. Piet could see that several contestants were beginning to struggle with the sheer volume of food they had consumed, their eating pace slowing noticeably as their bodies began to rebel against the continued intake. One contestant, a thin man in his twenties who had started strong, suddenly pushed back from the table with his hand over his mouth, apparently having reached his limit after just four and a half pies. The medical personnel stationed nearby moved quickly to assist him, though he waved them off and simply sat back in his chair looking defeated and slightly green around the edges.

By the eight-minute mark, a clear hierarchy had established itself among the remaining competitors. Derek Mills and Kevin Patel were locked in a tight battle at the front of the pack, each having completed seven pies and working steadily on their eighth. Jennifer van Rooyen was holding steady in third place, while the dark horse Andrew had quietly moved into fourth position with six completed pies and obvious capacity for more. Piet found himself in a three-way tie for fifth place, having just finished his fifth pie and feeling cautiously optimistic about his chances of moving up in the standings during the final seven minutes.

The crowd had grown more animated as the competition progressed, with spectators calling out encouragement to their favored contestants and maintaining a running commentary on the shifting dynamics of the race. Someone was keeping an unofficial scoreboard visible to the audience, updating the pie counts in real time and adding an element of sporting drama that elevated the event beyond mere novelty entertainment. Piet could hear his name mentioned occasionally by the commentators, usually in the context of "dark horse" or "steady performer," descriptions that seemed to capture his position as a serious contender who had avoided the early mistakes that had eliminated or hampered several of his competitors.

The ten-minute mark brought a announcement from the judge that seemed to inject new urgency into the proceedings. "Five minutes remaining, contestants. Time to dig deep if you want that trophy." The pace around the table immediately picked up, though not everyone was able to respond to the time pressure. Two more contestants had effectively dropped out of contention, reduced to picking at their food and looking as though they regretted ever hearing about pie eating competitions. But the remaining competitors seemed to find reserves of determination and digestive capacity that carried them into the final phase of the contest.

Derek Mills and Kevin Patel were now engaged in what could only be described as an epic battle for supremacy, each having completed eight pies and racing through their ninth with the kind of intensity usually reserved for Olympic finals. Derek's experience seemed to be serving him well - his eating technique remained efficient and controlled even under pressure, while Kevin appeared to be relying more on youthful enthusiasm and raw capacity. Behind them, Jennifer had solidified her hold on third place and was making a determined push toward nine pies of her own, though she appeared to be reaching the limits of her ability.

Piet had moved into clear fourth place by completing his sixth pie and making solid progress on his seventh, a position that surprised him with its competitiveness. He had expected to be happy with a respectable showing in his first competition, but now found himself genuinely contending for a podium finish and possibly even challenging for the championship itself if the leaders faltered in the final minutes. His stomach was definitely reaching capacity, but his eating technique remained efficient, and he could feel that he had avoided the kind of strategic errors that had derailed several other contestants.

The final three minutes of competition were unlike anything Piet had ever experienced, a combination of physical endurance test and mental challenge that required every bit of focus he could summon. Around the table, the remaining serious contenders were pushing themselves to their absolute limits, their faces flushed with effort and concentration. The sound of eating had taken on a more labored quality as tired jaw muscles worked through increasingly difficult chewing motions, and more than one contestant was showing signs of genuine physical distress as they approached the outer boundaries of their digestive capacity.

Derek Mills completed his ninth pie with two and a half minutes remaining and immediately reached for his tenth, though his pace had noticeably slowed and his usual controlled technique was beginning to show cracks under the pressure. Kevin Patel was struggling more visibly with his ninth pie, his initial burst of speed having given way to the kind of determined grinding that suggested he was running on willpower rather than natural ability. Jennifer had completed eight pies but appeared to be reaching her limit, taking longer breaks between bites and looking as though each swallow required conscious effort.

Piet finished his seventh pie and found himself facing a crucial decision about how aggressively to pursue his eighth. The morning sun cast long shadows across the dusty streets of Johannesburg as Piet Koetzee adjusted his worn leather tool belt and squinted at the electrical meter before him. Twenty-three years he'd been reading these contraptions, twenty-three years of crawling through ceiling spaces and rewiring suburban homes, and still the sight of perfectly balanced numbers gave him a small thrill of satisfaction.

"Another job well done," he muttered to himself, wiping sweat from his weathered brow with the back of his sleeve. The December heat was already becoming unbearable at half past eight in the morning, and Piet knew it would only get worse as the day progressed.

His van, a battered white Toyota Hiace that had seen better decades, sat parked under the shade of a blue gum tree. The vehicle bore the scars of countless encounters with Johannesburg's notorious potholes, its panels dented and paint faded to an indeterminate color somewhere between white and beige. But it ran, mostly, and that was all that mattered to a man like Piet.

As he loaded his tools into the back of the van, his phone buzzed against his hip. The caller ID showed his wife Sarah's name, and he smiled despite himself.

"Morning, my love," he answered, settling into the driver's seat.

"Piet, have you seen the newspaper today?" Sarah's voice crackled through the phone's speaker, excitement barely contained.

"You know I don't read that rubbish, Sarah. Nothing but politics and crime."

"Page fourteen, sports section. Trust me on this one."

Piet sighed and reached for the crumpled copy of The Star that lay on his passenger seat, folded open to the racing results from the night before. He flipped through the pages until he found what Sarah was referring to, and his eyes widened as he read the headline: "Annual Gauteng Pie Eating Championship Seeks Final Contestant."

The article explained that due to a last-minute withdrawal, the organizers were looking for one more participant to complete the field of twelve competitors for Saturday's final. Applications were being accepted until Thursday evening, with the winner receiving a cash prize of fifty thousand rand and the coveted Golden Fork trophy.

"Sarah, this is..." Piet's voice trailed off as he read the details again.

"This is your chance, Piet! You've been talking about entering one of these competitions for years."

She wasn't wrong. Piet had always possessed what could generously be called a healthy appetite, and what Sarah less generously referred to as "a bottomless pit where normal people keep their stomachs." At company braais, family gatherings, and church potlucks, Piet was legendary for his ability to consume vast quantities of food without apparent effort or consequence.

The idea of turning this particular talent into something resembling glory had always appealed to him, though he'd never quite found the courage to take the plunge. Competitive eating seemed like something that happened to other people, people with sponsors and training regimens and social media followings.

"What if I'm not good enough?" he asked, though even as the words left his mouth he knew they were ridiculous. Last month at his nephew's birthday party, he'd single-handedly finished an entire chocolate cake after the children had lost interest, and that was just as a warm-up to the main meal.

"Piet Koetzee, I've watched you eat six boerewors rolls at a single sitting without breaking a sweat. If anyone can win this thing, it's you."

The application process turned out to be surprisingly straightforward. A brief medical clearance from his doctor, confirming he was healthy enough to participate in what the form diplomatically termed "vigorous digestive activity," and a short essay explaining why he deserved the final spot.

Piet agonized over the essay for the better part of an evening, sitting at his kitchen table with a pen in one hand and a beer in the other, trying to find words that would convince the judges he was worthy. In the end, he kept it simple: "I've been eating pies my whole life, and I reckon I'm pretty good at it. Give me a chance to prove it."

The call came three days later, while Piet was elbow-deep in the fuse box of a suburban house in Randburg. The voice on the other end of the line was crisp and professional, belonging to a woman who introduced herself as Monica from the championship organizing committee.

"Mr. Koetzee, we're pleased to inform you that your application has been accepted. You'll be competing this Saturday at the Wanderers Club in Illovo, starting at two PM sharp."

Piet nearly dropped his phone into the tangle of wires he was working on. "Are you serious?"

"Completely serious, Mr. Koetzee. We'll need you to arrive by one-thirty for registration and a brief safety orientation. The competition format is straightforward - you'll have fifteen minutes to consume as many meat pies as possible. The contestant who eats the most wins."

After hanging up, Piet sat in stunned silence for several minutes, staring at the electrical panel without really seeing it. Then, gradually, a grin spread across his face that was so wide it made his cheeks ache.

That evening, Sarah insisted on taking him out to dinner to celebrate, though she made him promise not to overdo it.

"You need to start training properly," she said, cutting into her grilled chicken with surgical precision. "This isn't just about eating a lot anymore, Piet. This is about technique, strategy, endurance."

Piet nodded seriously, though privately he wondered how complicated it could be. Pie goes in mouth, mouth chews, stomach receives pie, repeat until victory. Still, he appreciated Sarah's enthusiasm for his newfound athletic career.

The next few days passed in a blur of preparation and nervous energy. Piet researched competitive eating techniques online, learning about jaw exercises and stomach capacity training. He practiced with various pie types, timing himself and experimenting with different approaches to maximize his consumption rate.

Friday evening found him sitting in his living room, surrounded by empty pie tins and feeling cautiously optimistic about his chances. His practice sessions had gone well - his personal best stood at seven standard meat pies in fifteen minutes, which he figured had to be competitive with whatever amateurs had signed up for the contest.

"You're going to do brilliantly," Sarah said, settling onto the couch beside him. "I can feel it."

Piet squeezed her hand, trying to project confidence he didn't entirely feel. "Just promise me you'll still love me if I come in last place."

"Piet, I've loved you through twenty-six years of marriage, three job changes, and that unfortunate incident with the Christmas pudding. I think I can handle watching you lose a pie eating contest."

Saturday morning arrived with the kind of perfect summer weather that made Piet grateful to live in Johannesburg despite its many flaws. The sky was cloudless, the temperature was perfect, and he felt as ready as a man could feel for such an endeavor.

He'd set his alarm for eight AM, giving himself plenty of time to shower, eat a light breakfast, and make the drive to Illovo. The Wanderers Club was perhaps forty-five minutes away in normal traffic, and Piet had factored in extra time for Saturday afternoon congestion.

Sarah kissed him goodbye at the front door, straightening his collar and brushing an imaginary speck of dust from his shoulder.

"Bring home that trophy, my champion," she said, and Piet felt his chest swell with something that might have been pride or might have been indigestion from his practice session the night before.

The van started on the third try, which Piet took as a good omen. He'd been meaning to have the starter motor looked at for months, but like most of his van's minor ailments, it was the sort of thing that seemed manageable until it suddenly wasn't.

He pulled out of his driveway at twelve-fifteen, giving himself what he considered a comfortable cushion of time for the journey ahead. The radio was playing some forgettable pop song, but Piet found himself humming along anyway, drumming his fingers against the steering wheel in anticipation of the afternoon ahead.

Traffic through the city center was lighter than expected, and Piet began to think he might arrive early enough to scout out the competition and maybe get a feel for the venue. He'd never been to the Wanderers Club before, but he imagined it would be suitably grand for such an important sporting event.

It was somewhere around Melville that the van began to make the noise.

At first, Piet thought the sound was coming from outside the van - perhaps a motorcycle with a faulty exhaust pipe or construction work somewhere nearby. It was a rhythmic grinding noise, like metal scraping against metal, accompanied by an intermittent clicking that seemed to sync with the rotation of his wheels. He turned down the radio and listened more carefully, his stomach sinking as he realized the sounds were definitely coming from beneath his own vehicle.

"Come on, old girl," he muttered, patting the dashboard with the kind of gentle encouragement he usually reserved for temperamental electrical circuits. "Not today. Any day but today." The van continued forward without any obvious loss of power, but the grinding noise grew more pronounced as he navigated the gentle hills leading toward the northern suburbs. Piet found himself gripping the steering wheel more tightly, his knuckles white against the cracked vinyl covering.

He considered pulling over to investigate, but a glance at his watch showed it was already twelve-forty. Even if traffic remained light, he was cutting things closer than he'd intended, and he couldn't afford to lose time diagnosing whatever was wrong with his increasingly unreliable mode of transportation. The noise was concerning, certainly, but the van was still moving, still responding to the accelerator and brake pedal, still getting him closer to his destination with each passing minute.

As he turned onto Jan Smuts Avenue, the grinding intensified to the point where other drivers were beginning to stare. A woman in a silver BMW pulled alongside him at a traffic light and gestured toward his wheels, her expression suggesting she thought he might be unaware of the mechanical symphony emanating from his vehicle. Piet smiled and waved, trying to project an air of confidence he absolutely did not feel. The light turned green, and he pressed the accelerator perhaps more gently than usual, willing the van to hold together for just a few more kilometers.

The irony of the situation was not lost on him. Here he was, a man who made his living fixing things that were broken, completely helpless to address whatever was failing in his own vehicle. He knew enough about cars to understand that grinding noises were rarely indicative of minor problems, and clicking sounds usually meant something important was coming loose or wearing out. But his expertise lay in circuits and wiring, not in the mechanical mysteries hidden beneath steel and rubber and grease.

By the time he reached Rosebank, the van was producing what could generously be described as a percussion ensemble of automotive distress. The grinding had been joined by a new squealing sound that seemed to crescendo whenever he applied the brakes, and there was now a distinct vibration running through the steering wheel that made his hands tingle with each revolution of the wheels. Other motorists were giving him a noticeably wide berth, as if mechanical failure might be contagious.

Piet began to calculate alternative transportation options in his head. He could call a taxi, but that would mean abandoning his van on the side of the road, and he had no idea how long it might take to get one during the Saturday afternoon rush. Public transport was theoretically possible, but the combination of buses and minibus taxis required to get him from wherever he might break down to the Wanderers Club would almost certainly make him late for registration. Sarah could come and fetch him, but she was visiting her sister in Krugersdorp and wouldn't be able to get to him quickly enough.
